metaData.descriptionCS: Examinee matches a symbol or word(s) with its corresponding picture, reads a simple instruction and performs the action, or reads passages and answers comprehension questions.

questions.title: Instructions for Items 1–4
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Point to the pictures from left to right as you name them and say, This means tree, this
means fish, this means car, this means bed, and this means bird.

questions.title: Item 1. tree
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Which one of these (point to the three symbols) means tree (point to the picture of the tree)?

questions.title: Item 2. bed
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Which one of these (point to the three symbols) means bed (point to the picture of the bed)?

questions.title: Item 3. fish
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Which one of these (point to the three symbols) means fish (point to the picture of the fish)?

questions.title: Item 4. bird
questions.topInstructionsHTML: ​Which one of these (point to the three symbols) means bird (point to the picture of the bird)?

questions.title: Item 5. stop sign
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

​This word (point to STOP) tells about this picture. What is this word?

questions.title: Item 6
questions.topInstructionsHTML: This word (point to WOMEN) tells about this picture (point to picture). What is this word?

questions.title: Item 7
questions.topInstructionsHTML: This word (point to RECYCLE) tells about this picture (point to picture). What is this word?

answers.html: commonly recycled objects such as paper, cans, or bottles

questions.title: †Item 8. bed
questions.incorrectInstructionsHTML:
†Incorrect or no response:

The word is bed. Touch the picture that this word tells about.

If the examinee does not touch the bed, say, Touch the picture of the bed. Teach further as needed and then say, Let’s try another one.​

Regardless of whether the examinee changes her or his response after teaching, record and score only the examinee’s original response.
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Now I want you to match pictures with words. Point to the word bed and say, Touch the picture that this word tells about.

questions.title: Item 9. cat
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Point to the word cat and say, Touch the picture that this word tells about.

questions.title: Item 10. bug
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Point to the word bug and say, Touch the picture that this word tells about.

questions.title: Item 11. pin
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Point to the word pin and say, Touch the picture that this word tells about.

questions.title: Item 12. log
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Point to the word log and say, Touch the picture that this word tells about.

questions.title: Item 13. pan
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Point to the word pan and say, Touch the picture that this word tells about.

questions.title: Item 14. bike
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Point to the word bike and say, Touch the picture that this word tells about.

questions.title: Item 15. farm
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Point to the word farm and say, Touch the picture that this word tells about.

questions.title: Item 16. drum
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Point to the word drum and say, Touch the picture that this word tells about.

questions.title: Item 17. sleeping
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Point to the word sleep and say, Touch the picture that this word tells about.

questions.title: Item 18. 1 fish
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Point to the words one fish and say, Now touch the picture that these two words tell about.

If the examinee touches two pictures, say, Touch the one picture that these two words tell about.

questions.title: Item 19. black star
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Point to the words black star and say, Touch the picture that these two words tell about.

questions.title: Item 20. red ball
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Point to the words red ball and say, Touch the picture that these two words tell about.

questions.title: Item 21. look up
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Point to the command and say, Do what this says.

questions.title: Item 22. clap hands
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the command and say, Do what this says.

questions.title: Item 23. say eye color
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the command and say, Do what this says.

answers.html: says eye color (any eye color is acceptable regardless of accuracy)

questions.title: Item 24. touch nose
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the command and say, Do what this says.

questions.title: Item 25. look behind
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the command and say, Do what this says.

questions.title: Item 26. apple
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Point to the sentence and say, Read this sentence and answer the question.

If necessary, point to the question (What did Pedro eat?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 27. running
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Point to the sentence and say, Read this sentence and answer the question. 

If necessary, point to the question (What is the girl doing?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 28. wrote a letter
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Point to the sentences and say, Read these sentences and answer the question.

If necessary, point to the question (What did Ana do first?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 29. tonight
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Point to the sentence and say, Read this sentence and answer the question.

If necessary, point to the question (When is Walter going to a movie?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 30 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Read this story and answer the questions. Say the number of each question when you answer it.

If necessary, point to the first question (Tell me who wants the milk.) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 31 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (Tell me who Toby is.) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 32 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. 

If necessary, point to the first question (How did Anika and Ying feel during their ride?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 33 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (Tell me what they were riding in.) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 34 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (How long was the ride?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 35 (4)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the fourth question (What in the story tells you that there were other balloons?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: Response that refers to communication with other travelers, or that quotes the phrase “other riders in the sky"

questions.title: Item 36 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions.

If necessary, point to the first question (What does a baby panda sound like?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 37 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (How long does it take before a baby panda begins to look like an adult?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: any specific number of months from 2 to 5

questions.title: Item 38 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (Which of these is true about baby pandas?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: a) They look just like grown-up pandas, only smaller.
b) They are black and white with pink fur.
d) They make no sound at all.
c) They are small enough to fit in a person’s hand.

questions.title: Item 39 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If starting here (or if necessary), point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. Say the number of each question when you answer it.

If necessary, point to the first question (How do the kids feel about their sitters for the night?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: Response indicating that this is a treat for them or they feel happy

questions.title: Item 40 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (Tell me a dish that the story says Mom cooks.) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 41 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (Who has come to sit with the kids?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 42 (4)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the fourth question (About how old is the speaker in this story?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 43 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. 

If necessary, point to the first question (What kind of card did Luis buy?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: one that talks (when you push a button)

questions.title: Item 44 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (What birthday card in the story could be eaten?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 45 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (Why didn’t Luis get the card with the spaceship?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.text: he didn’t want to sign the card

answerGroups.answersExplanation: he didn’t want to make up his own saying
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Refers to ONE of the following:

answers.text: he would have to write in it

answerGroups.answersExplanation: he didn’t want to write a message

scoreList.label: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 46 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. 

If necessary, point to the first question (What will save a flying car that runs out of gas?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 47 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (Based on the passage, why do you think few people will buy a flying car?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: will have to save up the money
Response indicating that the car is expensive

questions.title: Item 48 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (What is the best title for this story?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: c) How to Drive a Flying Car
d) Flying Cars Will Never Work
b) A New Way to Travel

questions.title: Item 49 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. 

If necessary, point to the first question (What did Blanca see in Peru?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: Any response that includes “the Great Wall of China”

questions.title: Item 50 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (How does Blanca get to visit all of these wonderful places?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: Response indicating that Blanca is not physically traveling

questions.title: Item 51 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (Which of the following could be called Blanca’s “ticket to adventure”?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 52 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. 

If necessary, point to the first question (What is the “new place” mentioned in the last sentence?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: the place he is moving to

questions.title: Item 53 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (Who arranged for Sean’s trip?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 54 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (Why might Sean be wiping away a tear?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: a) His father didn't want him to leave.
b) He's afraid of becoming sick during the trip.
d) He's afraid of being hungry in America.
c) He’s afraid he’ll never see his home again.

questions.title: Item 55 (4)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the fourth question (The primary reason for Sean’s trip to America concerns) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: c) his understandable need for a vacation.
d) his desire to visit his family in Boston.
e) his need to escape from the police.
a) his family’s misfortunes in Ireland.

questions.title: Item 56 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions.

If necessary, point to the first question (What does the legend say the phoenix does that first signals approaching death?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: sings and dives into the flames
Response that refers to singing but not to any subsequent actions other than building a pyre/fire

questions.title: Item 57 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (Where does the legend say the reborn phoenix comes from?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 58 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If starting here (or if necessary), point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. Say the number of each question when you answer it.

If necessary, point to the first question (Which employee would arrive late for work?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 59 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (Which employee would stay late when the store is especially busy?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 60 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (Which of the following can be assumed from the passage?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: b) The store manager dislikes Andy.
d) Jameel and Andy are not friends.
a) Jameel takes pride in his work.

questions.title: Item 61 (4)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the fourth question (What does Andy do when a coworker is sick?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: Response indicating that Andy doesn't help out

questions.title: Item 62 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions.

If necessary, point to the first question (What is the name of the puzzling disease?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 63 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (On what continent has the disease been reported?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 64 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (What causes elephants with this disease to die?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: Response indicating that eating or drinking is difficult or impossible
their muscles and nerves deteriorate and they can’t eat or drink

questions.title: Item 65 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If starting here (or if necessary), point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. Say the number of each question when you answer it.

If necessary, point to the first question (How was Hopper rewarded for her work?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 66 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (How did Hopper improve programming?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: made it so they could talk to computers
Response indicating that her system used English (or words) rather than formulas or math
invented a new language by inventing an English-based programming language
they didn’t have to use mathematical formulas

questions.title: Item 67 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (What would someone working with Hopper’s system see?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 68 (4)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the fourth question (What word best describes Hopper’s invention?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 69 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. 

If necessary, point to the first question (Name one example of space junk mentioned in the passage.) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 70 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (Why would a small piece of space junk cause damage?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: it’s a lot more powerful in space
it’s as fast as a bullet

questions.title: Item 71 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (To what does “products of their hard work” (lines 9–10) refer?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 72 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions.

If necessary, point to the first question (How does the visitor feel about the aunt?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 73 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (What does “giving up her firstborn son” (lines 8–9) mean?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: Response that mentions the son’s death or a euphemism for death

questions.title: Item 74 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (What word best describes the aunt’s attitude?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 75 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions.

If necessary, point to the first question (According to this passage, what type of energy source does not pollute the environment?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 76 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (What substance causes the groundwater to turn to steam?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 77 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (In the first sentence, what does “treads lightly” mean?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: Response indicating a figurative sense of the phrase, and that geothermal energy is not hard on the environment
causes little damage/not so disruptive to nature

questions.title: Item 78 (4)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the fourth question (Besides geothermal energy, what two other energy sources are mentioned in the passage?) and say, Now answer this question.

If the examinee names only one source, say, Yes, and what else?

answerGroups.answersExplanation: (burning fossil) fuel or specific fossil fuel (e.g., coal or oil)
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: One from EACH of the following:

scoreList.label: One from EACH of the following:

questions.title: Item 79 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. 

If necessary, point to the first question (How did the chance meeting make Mrs. Kennicott feel?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 80 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (What best illustrates the difference in social status between the driver and Mrs. Kennicott?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: a) the topic of their conversation
c) the fact that she is walking and he is driving
d) Mrs. Kennicott's refusal of the offer of a ride

questions.title: Item 81 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (How did Mrs. Kennicott feel in the town where she lived?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 82 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If starting here (or if necessary), point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions. Say the number of each question when you answer it.

If necessary, point to the first question (How old was Mascagni when he wrote Cavelleria Rusticana?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 83 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (According to the passage, how did Mascagni’s father feel about his son’s choice of profession?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 84 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (Why did Mascagni write his most famous work?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: show his father or family he could succeed

1.conditionalText: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 85 (4)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the fourth question (What is most surprising about Mascagni’s reputation?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: b) His family did not support his interest in music.
c) He wrote more than a dozen operas.
a) It is based on about one week’s work.

questions.title: Item 86 (5)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the fifth question (Cavelleria Rusticana includes how many acts?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 87 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions.

If necessary, point to the first question (Name one way in which the Richter scale differs from the Mercalli scale.) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.text: doesn’t rely on instruments (doesn’t specify which scale)
measures ground movements or seismic waves
has only one value or gives precise readings

answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Refers to ONE of the following:

scoreList.label: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 88 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (What is the main idea of this passage?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: b) The Mercalli scale is superior to the Richter scale.
c) Some earthquakes are more intense than others.
d) Scientists can describe earthquakes using more than one scale.

questions.title: Item 89 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (Why isn’t the Richter scale useful for studying ancient earthquakes?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.text: can’t measure stuff in the past
ancient earthquakes are no longer active

answerGroups.answersExplanation: Richter must be used while the earthquake happens.
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Refers to ONE of the following:

answerGroups.answersExplanation: Richter requires instruments unavailable at the time.

scoreList.label: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 90 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions.

If necessary, point to the first question (What is transferred to the blank paper?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 91 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (Name the type of developers that were used before Carlson invented xerography.) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 92 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (What is the role of static electricity in this process?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 93 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions.

If necessary, point to the first question (What is the poisonous element in this passage?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 94 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (What is the main focus of this passage?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: a) North American lizards in Australia
d) the effect of steroids on the heart

questions.title: Item 95 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions.

If necessary, point to the first question (To what does the author compare a crowd?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: leaves in a tempest or storm

1.conditionalText: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 96 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (According to the passage, what accounts for the survival of democracies?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 97 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (What is the main idea of the passage?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: a) Crowds tend to be destructive.
c) Crowd behavior has had a major impact on historical events.
d) Crowds tend to act in similar ways.
b) Crowds change quickly and unpredictably.

questions.title: Item 98 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If necessary, point to the paragraph and say, Read this story and answer the questions.

If necessary, point to the first question (In line 15, to whom does “he” refer?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 99 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the second question (Which sentence describes an irony?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 100 (3)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the third question (In line 12, what does “the mainland” refer to?) and say, Now answer this question.

answers.html: name of one or several European countries
European countries other than England or Ireland

questions.title: Item 101 (4)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: If necessary, point to the fourth question (According to the passage, Verdi probably saw his first Shakespearean play in what country?) and say, Now answer this question.

questions.title: Item 102 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
These sentences are part of a paragraph, but they are not in the right order. Read the sentences and decide what order they should go in. Then say the numbers of the sentences in the proper order. 

If the examinee appears to have finished reading the sentences but does not give an answer, say, What order should the sentences go in?

The examinee may use a pencil and paper to organize sentence numbers if he or she wishes.

answers.html: 4, 2, 5, 3, 1 (The examinee may say the numbers or read the sentences aloud.)

questions.title: Item 103 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: According to the passage, why did supernatural tales about mummies arise?

answers.html: to explain metaphysical occurrences such as death
the human desire to explain the inexplicable and our fears of death

questions.title: Item 104 (1)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Read these sentences and say the numbers in the proper order. 

If the examinee appears to have finished reading the sentences but does not give an answer, say, What order should they go in?

The examinee may use a pencil and paper to organize sentence numbers if he or she wishes.

answers.html: 5, 1, 4, 3, 2 (The examinee may say the numbers or read the sentences aloud.)

questions.title: Item 105 (2)
questions.topInstructionsHTML: How did a kylie differ from a boomerang?

answers.html: kylie is a hunting tool or weapon
kylie is straighter, or flies straighter
boomerang is curved more, or curves more

1.conditionalText: Refers to ONE of the following:

BasalConsecutiveZerosRule.reverseMessage: This subtest reverses after an imperfect score on this item.

observations.label: Had difficulty understanding the passages or questions, seemed confused or said, "That didn't make sense"
Referred back to the passage when unsure of an answer
